reviewText:
In 2004, when Doom 3 was released, it was a glimpse into the future. The game represented a huge leap in visual fidelity and even manages to hold up well today, over a decade later. Furthermore, the sound design is unsurpassed and really immerses the player in the experience. The environmental storytelling with audio logs and emails was way ahead of its time and would be replicated in future blockbusters such as Bioshock. It is a true testament to how ahead of its time this game was in 2004 that it holds up so well today.

I would highly recommend purchasing this version of Doom 3 over the BFG edition. First and foremost, the game was originally designed to have the player balance his use of flashlight and weapons. The BFG edition removes this gameplay element by allowing the player to use the flashlight and any weapon at the same time, removing some challenge from the game. The visual updates to the BFG edition are not substantial, search out comparison videos on YouTube for confirmation. This version will run perfect in 16:9 widescreen despite not having any 16:9 resolution options in the menu (requires modifying a .txt file).

I really enjoyed playing this game again (last time I played was 2004). Campaign took me 11.2 hours on medium difficulty without rushing through. The campaign is much longer than many contemporary AAA FPS games. This game has held up incredibly well and is still excellent in 2015. Highly recommended for any FPS fans.

reviewText: I'm going to give Doom 3 an actual recommendation because I really think it is one of the more underrated games. Doom 3 is iD's attempt to revitalize the classic Doom series 10 years later. Doom 3 departs from the explore the floor" style of older Doom games and is instead an attempt at a more linear/scripted action-horror game that was in my opinion pretty successful. The engine is a bit dated so the monsters don't have the frightening look going for them like the ones in newer games
date: but there's a great atmosphere that the game fosters of an invisible entity orchestrating the events happening around you. Most of the "spooks" come from the lights going out or the game applying the overused red filter to the display and then having a bunch of monsters come at you. While not nearly as frightening as Frictional's horror games (Penumbra/Amnesia)
recommended: the approach to horror it takes is closer to those games than something like Dead Space
hoursPlayed: which is more like "monsters jump out at you as a loud noise plays: the game". While there are a few "jump" bits in the game
voteText: most of what made me enjoy Doom 3 was the atmosphere and the background noise that contributed to the experience. The gameplay overall is closer to Quake II than Doom
helpfulPercent: with the more linear format but still having little secrets around you can find. Overall a decent successor to Doom in my opinion."

reviewText:
Doom 3 is a game that is very overlooked. It was Id's flagship title and features a very powerful game engine. It contained enhancements such as dynamic lighting, physics, bump mapping, portal technology among many other things we now take for granted. This was all months prior to Half Life 2 wowing us for the same thing.

Doom 3 is essentially a remake or reboot of the series. It shares virtually the same premise as the original Doom, except set on Mars instead of it's moons. In a way this sort of gives the game it's own style but makes it feel less original. The aesthetic of the game was nailed very well, however the levels do get very samey after a while. For the vast majority of the game you're mostly running through maze-like corridors looking for ways to open doors. This was the first game I remember where I started to notice maze-like level design felt antiquated. I always kind of wished this game was more open and less claustraphobic.

The game is still a horror game so they introduced dark environments with enemies shuffling around them. It also took a very bold risk where the player's flashlight is a separate weapon you equip. I personally like this mechanic but a lot of people, especially at the time hated it. And it was a frequent source of ridicule for the game.

The gunplay in Doom 3 is something I never particularly liked, especially compared to it's successor Quake 4. The pistol is a joke that is never used after you get the shotgun, the shotgun is what you use for 70% of the game, the machine gun's firing sound effect makes it sound like a cap gun, the chaingun is very slow and cumbersome, the rocket launcher is extremely cool but only used on bigger enemies, and the plasma gun feels too slow to be useful. This was all corrected with very fantastic modifications but at the time I can understand why people didn't like it.

In a way that's why I recommend this game. The engine Doom 3 used allowed it to be very heavily modified. There are a great deal of very good total conversion mods for the game, and it allowed Doom 3 to live on in our collective consciousness despite the game being only okay". I do recommend the game for it's modifications more than anything else since that is what this game is most remembered for.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=552871766"

reviewText:
Doom 3.
DOOM 3.
D00M 3.
What else is there to say about this unbelievablly awesome First Person Shooter/Survival Horror game?
This is possibly the greatest Reboot (Except for Wolfenstein the new order) ever made.

The story is good. Even though it's the same story as before, it is expanded on here: there is a whole deep narrative and sci-fi lore that is both mysterious, and exciting, without really getting in the way of the gameplay.

The voice acting, while ham-fisted, is awesome,

The Writing is great, as it was written the author Matthew J. Costello, and the story feels like something out of a science fiction epic, like Dune and Star Trek.

The ambiet noise & atmousphere?
I know there are a LOT of games with good ambiet noise, but
D00M 3 WINS HANDS DOWN, BEST AMBIET NOISE IN ANY VIDEOGAME MADE OR GOING TO BE MADE EVER.
There are so manny sounds atop of sounds atop of sounds underneith sounds ATOP OF SOUNDS, some you don't even hear; they're just THERE.  This extends to the Music.  Now it may look like there are only a few songs, but what you don't realise is that the ENVIRONMENT tells the music. You can hear the oxygen cycle and refreash the room you are in, and the chiming and grunting of machinery can make for some really interesting and creative music and sound.  It's the kind of stuff that you just don't see in videogames anymore.

The horror? Well, it may be cheezy, unoriginal, & full of jump-scares (Not jump-shocks or slender BS), but it feels VERY original for the time and since Doom was scary back in the day, you can't really critique this game for trying.

The opening is well paced, and it set's the mood for the game quite well. Even though Half-Life did it first, D00M 3 does an EXCELLENT job of it too, and sets you up for the odyssey ahead

The enemy designs are awesome: All (well, 85%) of the original monsters are back, with a few new ones (Those Zombie Commandos)

D00M 3 also has a HUUUUUUUUUUGE campaign length. Beating it would take roughly 12-17 hours to complete. What was that Killzone Shadow fall? only a 4 hour campaign??

The Weapons are ALL the same from Doom 1 & 2 (abiet updated ones), but you get a Machine gun to use (A good mid-range weapon), Grenades (Bouncy-Bouncy-Bouncy: hard to control but effective) & a Flashlight (Oh yeah...)

The game is VERY dark. That's one of it's selling points & why you should get D00M 3 & not the BFG edition: It's much more darker, & you can hold EITHER a flashlight or a gun. It might come off as annoying at first, but it sinks in, & it adds to the scare factor.

Keep in mind this is a VERY different DooM game, up to the point where people question if it is a DooM game at ALL.


But whatever you may think about D00M 3, it sold more than 5.3 million copies, making it the most successful game by it's developer id Software to date.

I VERY HIGHLY recommend D00M 3 to anyone who likes FPS, anyone who likes Horror-survival, & pretty much to anyone who loves video games in general.
This is a MUST PLAY
5/5




Editors Note: If you are going to play it, I highly recommend getting the Absolute HD mod for free off of Mod DB when playing this game: it makes it look a bit better, & it allows for modern resolutions without having to use the console commands.

reviewText:
Doom 3 is a no-holds barred, adrenaline pumped thrill ride; I've never played a game that's kept me quite on the edge of my seat or has had me gripping my mouse as tightly as this one. Doom 3 is scary, fast paced and frantic, and I highly recommend it.
This game is a first person shooter that has the player taking control of a Marine on Mars, who is forced to confront demons from Hell itself as they launch the space station on Mars into complete chaos; the story does not get much more complex and this, but hey, this is a Doom game, and I've never played the Doom series for story.
The game plays like many other games of the genre, with the player using guns to survive through each level; a simple premise, but effective, and shooting is well crafted here, considering this is what the Doom series is known for. All of the guns handle well and each kill feels satisfying and earned, and each fight will leave you feeling oddly relieved.
The atmosphere and sound design in this game is also quite good. Rather than hammering the player with an over the top musical score, this game prefers to use ambience to set the tone; creaks and groans of a decaying space station is far more effective at keeping the player on the edge of their seat. I found the dark environments great, as they left me in confusion as to where the next enemy would appear.
My only complaint would be that this game is rather short, and the multiplayer is non-existent nowadays. These are small complaints in comparison to the immeasurable quality of gaming that Doom 3 provides, and I recommend it highly to both novices and veterans of the first person shooter scene. 9 / 10

reviewText:
Let me list the good and bad things about this game.

First, this game has horrifying maps. I mean that in a good and bad way. It's scary, yes, but it also has these horrible twisting and looping maps that are so dark it's impossible to get through. Also when you first start the game, the weapons you have make pitiful attempts to injure some of the stronger enemies like Imps, though it gets better once you find more powerful weapons.

Now the good things.

If you're a fan of the original DOOM games, than YES BUY THIS! It's really fun for a DOOM fan to experience. It's awesome seeing the old pixelated monsters come to life in this game. Also, this game is truly terrifying. The darkness, and the constant demonic noises coming from your intercom make you barely have the courage to walk through the game. Overall, as a DOOM fan, I've enjoyed it. If you're new to the DOOM series, then go with the old ones, and see if you want to carry on with the epic saga of violence.

reviewText:
Don't be mistaken, DOOM 3 is in no way meant to be a successor to the original Doom games. But that doesn't at all mean it's a bad game, persay. Some may lambast it for being different, but it's no DNF for sure.

For one thing, DOOM 3's gameplay takes a slower pace than the last two games in the series and benefits greatly from this change. No longer are you speeding through levels, never taking one look backwards at the scene. Instead, the game builds up it's mood to supplement it's slower action.

Weapons mostly share the same functions as the old set from the originals and mostly feel like the original weapons in terms of gunplay. However, it adds a new variable in late game that rewards players for sustained killstreaks. However, the rocket launcher lose it's secondary utility in the closed-off levels.

Now, the enemy AI seems rather one-note. Basic zombies merely walk at a snail's pace towards the player, making it incredibly easy to pick them off at range. Imps merely run after the player, throwing homing fireballs all the while in combination with melee attacks.

But the Z-Sec and the Commando shows that their AI at least has some competency in it's making, if they're not very advanced. They make use of cover, strafe around and make ample use of manuevers in their combat. If I could make a comparison, they fight like the HECU from the original Half Life.

when console comes up type:

reviewText:
Probably the scariest game I've ever played.

Don't bother with the BFG edition despite what others may tell you.

One excuse they may say is that you can't play this version wide screen, well pfft I say, heres how:

C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\doom 3 ase

Create a new text doc, name it: autoexec.cfg

copy and paste into it:

seta r_customWidth 1920"
seta r_customHeight "1080"
seta r_mode "-1"
seta r_aspectRatio "1"

And DONE. Simple as that.

Many other reasons why its better :P"

reviewText:
Well I've been playing this game since over a month ago. Why has it taken me this long to play through it? Probably two things, distractions from other games and the repetition that Doom 3 has.

Doom 3 was made by id Software back in 2004 and it's sort of like a reboot to the original in a way since it doesn't follow the past two games. Just think of it like The Legend of Zelda as you can jump into any game at any time. No need to know any important storyline, not like there is much of a story. Doom 3 is about a scientist in Mars who has gone mad and opens a portal to hell killing nearly everbody thus you're the last marine who must stop the demons invading using the only skill you have. Starting a genicide on anything that the Pope does not approve of. There are some basic characters, cutscenes, even audiologs and emails to read which a lot of the time it's not all that interesting and the only reason to read and listen to said audiologs and emails is to get codes for supply caches.

Weapons are good but not great. You have a decent variety of weapons like the shotgun, SMG and rocket launcher. I enjoyed using the Plasma Gun and the BFG was fun the three times I ever got to use it. Enemies are diverse but are hit or miss. I hate the spider ones because who enjoys shooting a bunch of #!$@ing spiders in every game ever? Also some enemies leap at you as soon as you enter a room which is both unfair and gets annoying real quick. I also found it really weird how sometimes I can shoot an Imp with the shotgun in point blank range and it'll die but the same thing happens again and it takes two hits. I could be wrong but there is something very off about it, possible poor hit detection.

Level design is okay at first, it's really creepy and some noises of screams and creaks tend to unsettle me but sooner or later it's just a matter of entering a room, demons spawning and you gotta shoot them all. It becomes dull, predictable and annoying and some areas are really cramped so dodging an Imp fireball can be at times impossible which makes it again unfair. I found that after I entered and left Hell I got real sick of it and I consider the rest of the game (2-4 hours) to just be padding it out. It really angered me when all I just wanted to do was move forward but a door says I don't have clearence and I need to find a keycard for it. It's not that the environment changes much either. For 80% of the game you'll be in a dark corridor of some kind of science facility and it leaves me wanting a bit more variation.

I think this game has a lot of smaller problems rather than a couple of really big problems. It only shows the longer you play it. You can tell that Doom 3 was influenced by Half Life which is ironic considering Half Life was initially inspired by Doom. I don't think it's a bad game by any means, it's actually an alright game to play through but this wouldn't really be a top recommendation of mine. I'd go with something like Half Life or Bioshock first but that's just my personal tastes. If you're interested then it's worth a go and it goes on sale for very low often. I give it a 6/10.

reviewText:
You have heard of this game before, everyone has, so why not give it a try?

First off the main reasons to choose this over doom 3 bfg edition is that the chain gun and plasma gun fire faster, this version seems a bit more difficult, and there are more mods for this than there are for bfg edition. id did a magnificient job on the world in this game from the machinery that operates itself when there are no humans around, to the creepy audio logs and emails explaining how bad working on mars can really be. All weapons are powerful (not counting the pistol ofcourse) and play a different role in terms of combat, so you can use just the plasma gun but ammo will be scarce until later on in the game. The graphics certainly have aged since 2004 but thats not to say they are bad. The game looks fantastic without any HD mods and thats a minor complaint considering its 10 years old. The game is definitely creepy, while I personally was never scared to go into a dark hallway (mostly because I have such a devasting set of weapons to choose from) there are a lot of jump scares and a lot of random sounds that make the hair stand up on your neck. Not to mention the excellent sounds they used to amp the situation youre in.

Did I mention you can tear into demon babies with a chainsaw? That right there should be enough!! (though that is atleast halfway into the game).

reviewText:
On its own it's a good game, but it feels way too different from the first two games in the series to be called a DOOM game. Rather than having fast-paced action found in the first two games, fighting dozens, and sometimes dozens UPON dozens of enemies in large rooms, DOOM 3 stands out as being more of a horror game.

In contrast to DOOM 1 and DOOM 2, DOOM 3 is slower-paced and linear, with generally less space to move around freely and spray bullets like a madman at your enemies. You'll usually fight enemies either one at a time, or in small groups. If you like being spooked and having more than 2 guns at once, then you'll probably have fun with this game.

Oh yeah, the story. You're at a base on Mars and then demons.

(What the hell happened to the Cacodemons though, seriously: http://vignette1.wikia.nocookie.net/doom/images/d/d4/Cacodemon.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20110913092933)
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: Doom 3 lives up to its legacy and is a great game for fans of high-octane first person shooters.  The gunplay is great and the story is far superior to what I was expecting.  Many of your favorite enemies and weapons return and I found myself hooked on this game from start to finish.  That was about sixteen hours for me - an impressive length for a FPS and even more impressive that it held my attention.\n\nSince Doom is Doom, I won't go into the specifics as we all probably have the general idea already, but I will say that this is a great game that has stood the test of time.  I started playing this over a decade after it came out and it did not disappoint.  The graphics are a bit dated, but that's to be expected, and they are still good enough that I didn't feel that it detracted from the experience at all. I highly recommend this to first-person shooter fans and can easily say that it's a can't-miss game for fans of the old-school shooters like Duke Nukem, Quake, and... well... Doom.

reviewText: I didn't grow up during the golden era of Doom and Doom 2, so I don't have any cherished memories of either or those games. I do remember seeing my friend's older brother playing this game the night it came out over a decade ago, and man did it look great. The visuals were specacular, the setting and synopsis were intriguing, and the survival horror aspect of it captivated me. Doom 3 is a very slow paced shooter, and although you can sprint around and get into a few bigger firefights, you'll spend most of your time exploring confined areas and digging through PDAs and other interactables. In most other games I would find that to be a huge turn off, but the atmosphere building is this game wins me over every time. I just recently picked up the new Doom (2016) and have been enjoying the hell out of it (badumtiss) but for very different reasons. If you want to scratch your itch for a horror/story heavy game with less twitch shooting, this will do you well. If plot and tension aren't your thing but you really want to gore some demons in fast motion, Doom 2016 is the better choice.

reviewText:
Demons from mars.

DOOM 3 is classic action-horror game. It was a re-boot to the 'DOOM' series, abandoning open environment for the traditional jump scares.

PlotYou play as an unnammed marine who has been recently transfered to the Mars Space Station run by the UAC. As you can expect, things on mars aren't as they seem and soon demons take over the station. It is your job to send these freaks back to where they came from.

GameplayMajority of the game is shooting and collecting items. You have a wide range of weapons including pistol, shotgun, machine gun, grenades, chainsaw, pulse rifle. If your feeling crazy, you can even use your fists. Levels are seperated via areas on the station, with each area reached by elevator or other transport. You have both health and armor which you can replenish via pick up items. Ammo can be found in the area or dropped from foes. You face a variety of foes such as zombies, security, skulls, imps, hell knight and other foes which take inspiration from previous entries. There are also boss battles which occur in later levels.

AudioMusic is excellent at instilling the dark atmosphere. There isn't much background music during gameplay, which makes you focus on the various sounds such and creaks and footsteps nearby, keeping players feeling edgy and uncomfortable.

ConclusionIf you are looking for a good action horror game, Doom 3 will not dissapoint.

reviewText:
It may be the most slow paced Doom, but damn if it isn't cool and innovative.

It has cool touch screen panels you interact with your mouse, and a bottomless pit of (some clever) jumpscares.

Some weapons have their ammo count on the actual gun, instead of a HUD element, neat.

Some characters look a bit wonky, notably around the head area. However, the environments are well detailed, even if it's much of the same. Also, the shadows are so heavy, I feel like theres a 50 pound weight on my head whenever I'm under a shadow. It's like those damn F.E.A.R./Condemned: Criminal Origins shadows, but even heavier.

There's a bunch of audio logs and PDAs you can shuffle throughout the game for some optional dialogue/text and whatnot, as well as some codes for unlocking lockers/rooms for equipment and items.

Combat is pretty fun, shoot a zombie up close in the face with a shotgun, they hit the floor harder than a slab of meat made out of brick. A chainsaw with unlimited fuel to wreak havoc, up close and personal like. Rocket Launcher that make demons go boom, and an overly expensive experimental energy weapon, the BFG 9000 that wrecks rooms clean.

It's an immersive horror FPS with demons n' ♥♥♥♥ coming out the walls. Play it on max graphics, and on hard difficulty, with death metal playing in the background in complete darkness for maximum effect.

reviewText:
Despite its somewhat underwhelming reputation I couldn't love this game more.
Its true the game has more than its fair share of dark spots, but, well... I call myself a cat I guess darkness is kinda my thing. :P  I actually really like the infamous flashlight mechanic, it adds tension and fear to environments that wouldn't be particularly scary -- and in the BFG edition where that mechanic is removed, they aren't.
The combat is fun and fast-paced, if a bit repetitive, but the variety with certain monsters like Arch-Viles takes some of the repetitiveness out of it once you get deep into the campaign.  The boss fights are really fun with unique mechanics except, somewhat, for the last one -- and they strike a good balance when it comes to difficulty: you'll finish them without much health left but you probably won't die so much it gets frustrating.  Hard mode is very fun as it's not about hiding or taking cover -- the way the monsters spawn you have to be pretty ferocious in order to survive.
Map design is actually not too linear, which is a good thing to see in a game even as old as 2004... levels are maze-like without being confusing, and there's a decent variation in texture and structure schemes especially toward the end of the game -- although that part could still be improved somewhat.  Coming to this as I did about 8 years after it was released this type of level design was like a breath of fresh air.
Graphics are still beautiful even 12 years later, the monsters and especially boss designs are grotesque and disturbing, they really feel like they could be demons out of some hell.

There are a few minor quibbles I have -- just a few straighforward ones, and one or two weird ones...
In a 27-level campaign, a lot of the monsters only appear for three or four levels or stop appearing altogether just after the mid-point.  This seems to especially happen to the most interesting designs like a literal baby insect, the (somewhat) classic lost soul, and the... Mancubus... thing...  Even the ubiquitous Pinky Demon from the original games kinda disappears after the fifteenth map or so.  There are plenty of other monsters that appear later on but it would have been nice to see some demons from the earlier maps stick around especially when enemy variety is one of the game's strong points.
The weapons tend to be kinda same-ish although there's still enough variety to go around and enough situations where you do want to switch from one to the other.  You do have a bloody chainsaw if you get bored and it works well on even some of the high-level monsters like Arch-Viles, but the weapons are still a weak point.  I find myself mostly using the shotgun even when another weapon would work just as well -- it seems even limiting the amount of shotgun ammo you can find or carry (there doesn't seem to be any maximum, or if there is it's so high I've never reached it) would have gone a long way towards resolving this.  Its ammo does get more scarce towards the end of the game but so does the ammo for everything else, leaving you in the same situation.
Finally -- and this is the weird one -- some of the monster sounds are distorted samples taken from tiger calls.  I spend a decent amount of time around tigers and these calls are, quite clearly, chuffs" (a kind of purr) and mating calls.  I guess Pinky's a succubus now? :P  It can get pretty hard to take a hellish monster seriously when it's literally purring at you.
Interestingly enough
date: the gameplay isn't the only place you can find big cat sounds in this game...\n\nAll in all this is a great game
recommended: with a lot of custom content as well that I haven't gone into here just 'cuz I've already been talking long enough.  An underrated classic
hoursPlayed: I highly recommend giving it a look if all you've heard is its reputation for dark spaces and a weird flashlight."

reviewText:
Doom 3. What can be said about Doom 3? It's the third game in a long line of games that helped revolutionize the FPS genre. It's also the game that came out around the same time as Half-Life 2, as well as deviating from the run and gun playstyle from the first two, instead opting for a more horror survival gameplay and making lighting a central theme around it as well, has it aged well?

I'd say yes. I think the initial disappointment from a lot of fans came as a result of this game not being the same as the first two, and honestly, in my opinion, I don't think that's a bad thing at all. It's a slower paced game than its predecessors that's for sure, fleshing out its story and narrative through ingame cutscenes and chracter's PDA's, similar to what modern games nowadays are doing... think like BioShock. A lot of people also had complaints with the flashlight system, which is (imo) what lends to the tension you feel throughout the whole game. If you have issues with that however, there's mods, as well the BFG edition which remedies this (which also brightens up some textures from my understanding), but in my opinion that takes away from the atmosphere they were going for in this game. They consciously made the design choice of making you choose between having your gun out, or your flashlight out to scout the darkness, the light giving you a sense of comfort while also leaving you completely defenseless while doing so. Granted, there are some moments when certain enemies will cheaply spawn behind you, or in complete darkness.

The game is also a lot longer than I remember it being, its single player campaign clocking in at around 10-15 hours, depending on how you approach things, although to be fair, I think the game starts off kind of slow, easing the player into the narrative before all hell breaks loose. The latter half of the game being very action packed moreso than the beginning.  I think this game was ahead of its time, and I feel it's not as fondly remembered as HL2, but I still think it's a great experience, and one of the last Doom games to be developed by the original id team, before the license was shipped over to Bethesda, definitely an end of an era.

Closing out, I have to say I played through it with a graphics mod, to bring the graphics up to date a bit, there's several of them out there but the one I installed was Doom 3 Redux, you can find it among others over on the moddb site.

I highly recommend to fans of survival horrors, and first person shooters. One of the better titles that came out during that era. Would definitely suggest playing it with an HD texture pack as well, the game holds up suprisingly well when using them.

reviewText:
While Doom 3 is not a 100% action drived shooter like the old ones, it is still a fantastic game.

Rather than being a sequel to Doom II, Doom 3 is more or less a remake of the first Doom, putting more emphasis on story and atmosphere than the previous games.

You once again play a nameless Marine who arrives on Mars. Rather than start right in on the action, your first assignment is simply check up on a scientist that is working on a project that is quite big.
Of course, it doesn't take long for everything to go to ♥♥♥♥. Hell quickly invades the base and of course its up to you to fix EVERYTHING.

The narrative is pretty good, and its simplicity doesnt deter from the games action. The game itself is dark and scary, which even though it relies on jump scares quite a lot, it still feels nice and the ambience is great.

In alot of aspects, the game feels alot like the PSX port of Doom, relying on scare factor than badass factor. Yeah you still ♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ up ALL BY YOURSELF but you do still feel like you can easily be brought down, which when done right (as it is here.) , creates a really enjoyable experience.

reviewText:
First off, it is actually possible to run Doom 3 natively on Linux. (Google is your friend in this regard.) If you do so, the Linux installation will be independent of Steam, although it will be dependent on the CD key which is also provided by Steam. (Which is why my time played appears much lower than it actually is.) So that's a thing.

Doom 3 is an excellent FPS. It is a game where most weapons feel powerful and a little bit of tactical movement will go a long way. Here's what I mean by tactical movement: I see an imp, dodge its fireball, and immediately sprint up to it and give it a shotgun blast before it can retaliate. When a Revenant fires at me, I move backwards along a tight circular path to throw off the rocket's homing capability. Generally, dodge and counterattack will be a pretty common habit within this game.

While the weapons are pretty standard, they do their job quite nicely. A rocket will send a ragdoll flying, the chaingun makes a thunderous hail of death, the plasma gun lays down a huge volume of fire (and can even block projectiles when used by a sufficiently skilled player), the chainsaw is so effective that it kills the atmosphere, and the BFG literally destroys everything in sight.

Except for lousy model quality, I think that this game is very nice looking and has aged rather well. This is one of its cardinal sins: if a game has great graphics but not a memorable story, it will be forever branded as a tech demo because you can't please everyone with just your gameplay.

As for story, the story is basic and somewhat cliche, but I do love the character of Dr. Betruger. But if you're a story freak and possibly a cynic in that regard, then you will have a bad time.

And this game is long to the point of being a fault. It feels like it should be over at the end of the hell level, but it just keeps going. (Granted there are some fun encounters after that point.)

By the way, don't worry about the flashlight. People complain about how you have to choose between holding a gun or a flashlight, but the only enemies you will fight when you need the light are zombies, which won't be much of a problem, and imps, which obligingly light themselves up for your convenience.

Ultimitately, I can't tell you whether or not you will enjoy Doom 3, but I personally think that it is a high quality shooter and that at the very least you should pick it up on sale if you have any interest at all.

reviewText:
2004 was a big year for gaming. Metal Gear Solid 3 rocked the then-developing Stealth-Action genre, Ninja Gaiden rebooted the dormant NES franchise, Silent Hill 4 sent it's series down a long, dark path (and not in a good way), and we were met with numerous first person shooters: Halo 2, Far Cry, Painkiller, Half-Life 2, Counter Strike: Source, and this gem, Doom 3.
Part of the reason why Doom 3 was such a big deal, was the fact that it was a huge departure from the traditional Doom formula. The first two Doom games were simple, straightforward shooters. Here are the bad guys, kill all of them, get to the end of the area. It was super fast-paced, and pumped full of adrenaline. There wasn't much of a story, besides a few walls of text between episodes or levels. Doom 3 had a slower, more sinister approach. The story is much more prominent, being written by Sci-Fi author Matthew Costello. Besides infrequent cutscenes, there are also audio logs, similar to System Shock 2, which help tell the lore of the game. The game is also more horror-focused than Doom 1 and 2. Back then, jump scares really weren't a thing. Doom 3 is partly to blame for the prominence of jump scares, however, this does them right.
Doom 3 was also a big deal due to the new lighting engine it had. Back then, there was nothing like it, and a lot of games still don't have dynamic lighting this good. id Software really showed the gaming world what it could do with this game, and it's impressive.





10/10
It's okay. I guess.

Played a lot this game when it came out. Don't let the great gunplay of this game fool you: no matter how badass those weapons are, monsters and atmosphere is still gonna scare you a lot. If you miss the old school shooting or like horror

If you think a good FPS needs to have samey infantry enemies (guys with gun wich you kill with guns), dogs, and homogeneized gunplay where the SMGs, Assault Rifles, Carbines, and LMGs have magically the same balistic precision, don't get this game. But please point a real gun at your face and pull the trigger. Games as good as this are very few thanks to that.

reviewText:
Doom 3 is a astounding game that combines the First Person Shooter style-gameplay of previous Doom games with revolutionary graphics that still stand up to modern titles. I prefer the original to the BFG Edition as Doom 3 was one of the first games I got on Steam and holds a special place in my heart.

The scares still get me everytime, even though I've played through the game in it's entirety several times.

Nothing compares to the satisfaction of pumping an Imp coming at you down a dimly-lit corridor with led from your trusty shotgun, still being wary of what's around every dark corner.

In addition, the lighting was one of the most hyped up things about this game, and boy does it deserve it. The lighting in this game is great even by modern standards, the dynamic lighting is realistic and I honestly enjoy taking in the scenery of the Mars Base.

The sound effects are quite nice, and the monsters genuinely sound intimidating, I jump everytime I hear something behind me in a blood-showered hallway with flickering lights, because I know that means it's back to Demon Killing.

I'd recommend this game to any fan of previous Doom games, fans of Horror, fans of FPS games, or a combination of all those things.

reviewText:
This game divides people’s opinions to the point where very few games are this polarising, you have what are called the doom purists who absolutely hate this game because it’s not a carbon copy of the originals and you have people who do like it. So this begs the question of how doom-like this game really is.

Similarities:

There is a lot of satanic and gory imagery.

The weapons are the same with a small handful of new editions being: grenades and a machinegun.

The enemies are the same (though some enemies move quicker than the original counterparts and some move slower than the original counterparts, and some are a little weaker than before.) with a few new editions.

The enemies are very predictable and once you know how they function you can use that to your advantage to take them out with the right weapon for the situation and avoid taking damage just like the originals.

There are monster closets everywhere which open when you pick up a specific item and or walk past a specific point just like the originals.

You move level to level just like in the originals.

There are still key hunts and or the equivalent to key hunts.

There are moments where it’s so dark that you can barely see anything just like in the originals.

The game still has secrets and you can find some of the weapons earlier than you would usually find weapons just like in the originals and every old school shooter ever made.

Differences:

Having said that about darkness, doom 3 is very dark for most of the game, and you have to pull out a torch separately rather than having a torch tapped to a gun, this is one of the major criticisms of the game, I don’t have any issues with it, because it’s actually a lot better than the torch in the BFG edition where you can have a torch with another weapon however it’s too far to the left and it runs out of battery really quickly.

You move a lot slower to a more realistic jog and running with a stamina bar whereas in the originals you move at 60mph all of the time.

The enemy count is much sparser and the maximum amount of enemies you will usually have on screen at once is four to eight, whereas in doom 1 it was around fifth teen to twenty, and doom 2 it was around forty, though a lone enemy in doom 3 can be a lot more dangerous than a lone enemy in the originals.

The levels themselves are a lot narrower than before though there are still some open areas here and there.

Sometimes you might have an actual objective to complete and you sometimes come across NPCs and these sentry drones who fight alongside you.

They have tried to have an actual plot but thankfully it’s pretty avoidable and ignorable, and at the end of the day it’s pretty much the same thing as the original plot, and there’s also an emphasis on finding codes for doors and storage cabinets.

There is a focus on horror and some little scripted sequences but that thing is subjective from person to person.

The weapon viability has also been changed around: The fists are just as a very last resort as before however the berserk power up is so rare you only come across it twice, the chainsaw is exactly the same, the torch is good against the unarmed zombies, the pistol is a last resort however unlike the originals it has perfect accuracy, unlike the first game where the shotgun is the go to gun most of the time since it has ridiculously good range and accuracy for a shotgun, the shotgun in doom 3 is only good to use at short to close range due to the large amount of spread, and it has a lower rate of fire, this gun is good to use against the weaker enemies such as the first game. (People complain that the shotgun is really overpowered in doom 3 however it’s the same as the first game in the sense that all of the enemies that can die in one hit in doom 3 can die in one hit in the originals) The machinegun is good for the medium enemies at for when the enemies are at a longer range. The minigun is a heavy weapon this time around and it is good for the heavy enemies and just any enemies though I find myself using it on the heavy enemies when they are too close for the rocket launcher. The grenades are almost useless since they bounce around too much. The plasma guns role is unchanged from the originals. The rocket launcher is good for the heavier enemies and boss fights, and finally the BFG…sadly I only find myself using it twice which are for two different boss fights, whereas in the doom 2 it is very useful for taking out a group of enemies and enemies you want to kill as quickly as possible.


If there’s one problem with Doom 3 it’s that you can’t switch weapons when you reload, that doesn’t sound like much and it also happens in a few other games as well, but in this it means the difference between life and death because you’ll have three or four enemies rushing at you and there’s nothing you can do about it because you are stuck in a reload animation.

Don't get the bfg edition, because it ruins a lot of things in the game: it's far too bright so it basically turns down the atmosphere, there is a crappy torch that you can now use and have a gun out at the same time but it is too far to the left and runs out of battery too quickly, and it's supposed to be a HD re-mastered version of the game and it doesn't look any different, and it is very dumbed down and made far too easy to the point where the explosive barrels do ♥♥♥♥ all, there are too much health and ammo pickups lying around, the enemies do far less damage, and in the expansion pack there's even one section that was removed from the game! (That being that large room with all of the pillars and enemies in hell) Be sure to get the original version.

I love this game as much as the originals though doom 2 is my favourite, this is really one of those games where you have to try it for yourself because of how polarising it is.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm going to be Really Honest, DOOM 3 wasn't the Best Entry in the Series for me, but its still a Pretty Game no matter what.

Pros+
+Good Gameplay.
+Creepy Atmosphere.
+Good Level Design.
+Some of the Enemy Models are well made, they kinda look as if H.R. Gieger Designed them.
+A Sinister Villain (Dr. Betruger).
+Has Mod Support.

Cons-
-Level Design whilst Impressive is Very Linear, Narrow Coridors and Almost little to no Alternative Paths, there are some Secret Areas though like in the Original DOOM.

-A Majority of the Story Elements were Copied from Half-Life, though to be Fair Technicaly Speaking Half-Life did Copy some Story Elements from the Original DOOM & its Successor Quake.

-Some of the Weapons are Good, but some of the others are Pretty Wimpy Compared to their Counterparts in the Original DOOM, Shotgun and Chaingun for Example.

-Suspense is Ruined by Cheap Jumpscares and Cutscenes revealing the Monsters.

-Handheld Flashlight, this makes sense in a Survival Horror Game like Penumbra, but not a Game like DOOM 3 which is Focused on Action.

-The Visuals would have been Impressive for the Time DOOM 3 was Released, but to this Day its Visuals have Aged Poorly, alot of the Models and Map Textures have this Glossy Texturing that makes them look as if they were made from Plastic.

No Matter what I didn't like about this Game, I still Enjoyed it.

8/10 Inverted Pentagrams.

reviewText:
One of my favorite games of all time! However, this game is not without it's caveats, the main one being the lack of basic equipment on a futuristic colony on Mars.

You mean to tell me that over a hundred years into the future, combat marines will be left running around in the dark without night vision goggles or even a $5 headlamp? All you have is an old Mag light that you have to switch back and forth from your weapons meaning you can not protect yourself with a gun and defend yourself at the same time. This makes no sense, why doesn't the main protagonist just duct tape the flashlight to his rifle, do they not have duct tape in the 22nd century?

This problem was so bad I hear someone online even made a patch specifically to fix this problem where it makes the flashlight work even when you are holding a weapon.

Despite it's problems, it's still a great game and a must play for any FPS fan.

reviewText:
One of my favorite games of all time! However, this game is not without it's caveats, the main one being the lack of basic equipment on a futuristic colony on Mars.

You mean to tell me that over a hundred years into the future, combat marines will be left running around in the dark without night vision goggles or even a $5 headlamp? All you have is an old Mag light that you have to switch back and forth from your weapons meaning you can not protect yourself with a gun and defend yourself at the same time. This makes no sense, why doesn't the main protagonist just duct tape the flashlight to his rifle, do they not have duct tape in the 22nd century?

This problem was so bad I hear someone online even made a patch specifically to fix this problem where it makes the flashlight work even when you are holding a weapon.

Despite it's problems, it's still a great game and a must play for any FPS fan.

reviewText:
Despite the facts that there were some certain flaws in the game (i.e. no military nightvision, no flashlight on weapons, overused horror cliches, etc.), those flaws do make the good parts of Doom 3 all the more better, specifically that the Doom 3 has its own level of challenge, especially when fighting in the dark. Not only that, but Doom 3 is modular! You can make custom maps and stuff to play Doom 3 in. While the BFG edition is a lot more graphically better, you can get a mod for this original version that will match it or even outbest it (Not that I'm trying to put down the BFG edition, of course.)

Also, let's not forget the Nightmare difficulty, which introduces a degenerating health system that won't kill you, but makes you so weak as in a single hit from almost any enemy can be enough to kill you.

A 2004 classic to love!

reviewText: I admit that I'm one of the many who gave this game all kinds of hate eversince I played it for the first time. I can't say it's completely my fault since the game does leave a terrible first impression with it's extremely slow pace and stupid scripted events. It's not until about 3 or 4 hours into the game that this game becomes Doom. I bought this game cheap on sale and decided to give it another go since playing it for the first time on the original XBOX. The game makes you think that all you're going to get is a little action in between reading emails, listening to logs, waiting through cutscenes. Well I'm glad to say that you won't. Collect all the PDAs you can find and just scan the emails to see if you can get codes to the weapon lockers so you can stay well stocked on ammo. Other than that you can pretty much ignore everything else.\n\nBy the time you reach the end of this game you will know that you've played Doom. No, you don't flip a switch or collect a key to open up multiple closets full of enemies, but enemies do spawn all around you and will cut you down quickly if you don't dispatch them quick enough and strategize your reloads well. If you're a fan of Doom, you should play this game.

reviewText:
Although this game by itself is good enough to be considered a pretty nice game, it lacks of the DOOM essence first introduced with Knee-Deep in the Dead. The gameplay is not as linear as the older ones, and it is full of reading and cinematics. Nothing more boring in a DOOM game if you ask me.

However, the value of this game is not within the game itself, but within its engine and source code. Many modders have made a wonderful job creating new content for this engine. And one of the best of them is a recreation of the first installment of DOOM, Knee-Deep in the Dead, brought up-to-date with modern effects, AI, sounds and triggers!

You can see it by yourself: http://youtu.be/nn0Z1ZdZwIk http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iNReuxRlsLo
And you can grab it from here: http://www.moddb.com/mods/classic-doom-3

This mod is the reason I bought this game on Steam. This mod is everything I hold dear in this good Earth (or this good Mars?). BFG edition won't allow mods, so this installment, rather cheap, is a must-have for every DOOM fan, because that mod is pure dynamite and worth its source code lenght in diamonds.

reviewText:
Doom 3 was a hit when it came out and is an absolutely necessary game to play if you are a fan of the original doom series.  There are pros and cons, however, to this game.  It seems that id tried harder to create a horror game than an action game.  The original Doom games were screens filled with enemies to take out with over the top action.  Here the action is still over the top, but you fight against a maximum of 5 creates at a time at the most, and not screens full of enemies.  This changes the pace of the game and lowers the bar for the action a bit.  Also, by trying to make it scary, the levels are very dark.  This is too bad because the graphics are beautiful, but hard to see when the lighting is so low.  I would say though that the graphics compared to Source didn't age as well when compared to today's graphic abilities.

However, this is still Doom.  This is still a game of kill or be killed and you are still a bad ♥♥♥ with a gun.  All of the old guns come back from the previous games and they feel great.  The levels are corridor levels, and not open areas, but that helps with making this more of a horror game.  The sounds are good and the music is pretty much the same as quake with a heavy metal focus.

Do I like this game better than I loved the original Doom, no.  But I can't not recommend this game, as the graphics and its brand name set a standard that all other games of the future look to copy or surpass.  id did not make the impact with Doom 3 as they did with the original Doom, but this is still worth your time playing.

reviewText: DOOM 3 is a FPS that isn't quite the same as its predecessors, but it's good in its on unique way. DOOM 3 employs more darker levels, horror and fear tactics (enemies popping out from hidden walls or teleporting around you) which works very well. The graphics and attention to detail all look great and the level designs are a lot tighter and have the player traversing through a lot of hallways and corridors. The campaign is ~8-10 hours long so it's a lot longer than most campaigns. During the middle it becomes a little repetitive as you constantly have to find PDAs or some item before you can open a door but then near the end the game really kicks into another gear and ends on a high note. DOOM 3 is a solid FPS shooter that also may have the player jump out of the seat once or twice!

reviewText:
There isnt much to say about Doom 3 except that the game was simply brillant. This game is a horror classic.
If you are somebody that likes Call of Duty, or just a simple horror game, then this game is definetely for you. Doom 3 is about a marine in the year 2145 that goes on a ship to complete his mission. During the time he is on the space ship, hell breaks loose. There are demons, deadly spiders , zombies , and many fun to fight bosses. Again if you like either horror or FPS shooters than you really should play Doom 3.

This game, believe it or not, is a decade old.  Even with that considered, it still looks pretty decent to this day.  I highly recommend this game over the new BFG version for a number of reasons both subjective and objective.

The objective reason is obvious, that being that sikk mod (may be wrong spelling), along with the wolfsomething texture pack make it look even better than the BFG edition.

The rest is subjective.  I have heard and seen play throughs of the new lost mission in the BFG edition.  Not only does it make no sense along the lines of Aliens Colonial Marines with Michael Bean still being alive, but the levels are not very compelling.

Overall if you can get the origional with the classic flashlight with no gun I suggest playing this game on hard, without the ducktape mod.  The game was designed with this as a game mechanic even though, from what I have heard it was a technical compromise.  One interesting thing about the new BFG version with the suit flashlight is that there are no shadows.  Where as with the hand held flashlight there are.  Carmack evidently wanted flashlight design to go in one direction while the industry took another.  This is why for those of you who played quake 4, using the same engine, you can see your allied NPcs flashlights, but in left 4 dead you cannot.

Back to the game and less about tech history.

This game has good graphics even without mods.  It was one of those games that when it came out was hands down the best looking thing out on the market.  If your keen about moding, I mentioned a really good texture pack above.  The game has a nice variety of enemies and guns.  This is a game back in the days where you did not need 10 smgs, 10 asault rifles, and so on.  You get your standard shotgun, machine gun, plasma gun, and BFG!!!

Despite people calling most enemies idiots you will die a few times on hard so save often.  There is some strategy such as with the tentecal commando.  Knowing to let him run up to you and duck, shoot, stand, shoot in the face is a hard but excellent tactic. (timing wise you can mess up and die real fast)  Also start the game on hard.  Any horror game (im not saying this is survival horror, but it applies to that as well) should in my humble opinion be played on the hardest difficulty available, in the dark, and with a headset.  As scary as the artwork or demonic base can get, its not very scary if your enemies are a joke.  Since there is no regenerating health you will find yourself with 32 hp on many occasions, one hit away from death from a hard ememy.  Thats tension baby!

Also while this is entirely up to you, I must say playing with the basic flashlight design really makes or breaks the game for me.  Having played it with both, I cannot stress how there is worse lighting and less tension.  Yes I know a flashlight is one of the basic attachments to any gun and it makes no sense, but we are playing a game about demons from hell.  The flashlight leaves you vulnerable and makes you slowly explore rooms until hell breaks loose.  Also slowing down allows you to hear enemies hiding.  Ive often used the tactic of fill the room with grenades and then enter (Careful those things love to blow you up).  The game does have monster closets, and while cheap, they do scare you and I honestly hated them in 2004, but really came to like them when I replayed recently.  In the end its your choice about the flashlight, just know it will change the game experience.

Multiplayer is dead so your getting this for the singleplayer.  Overall its a nice scary walk through time.  Hope this was helpful, if not let me know why so I can improve.
For any HL2 lover. Somewhat old, but worth it, definately. A must have for anyone who loves shooters.

Zombies/Demon Goblins/Demon Bears/Robot Skeletons/etc. jump out of every nook and cranny to have a taste of your famed shotgun pellets. Also the shadows are REALLY good.

If you've ever played Doom, you know it's a fast-paced run and gun shooter. Doom 3 still is, but it is distinctly slower, putting more emphasis on atmosphere instead. The lighting engine was very advanced for the time and it really helps to set the mood when you see huge, menacing shadows fly by the walls cast by demons running through low angle lighting.

That said, the whole game is dark. You get a flashlight, but you have to choose between equipping it or wielding a weapon. That fact has garnered a lot of flak for the game, but I didn't mind it. Forcing you to hold your flashlight at the cost of disarming yourself made simply walking down a corridor feel intense.

The majority of the game takes place in a research facility on Mars, which grants a sense of isolation. You know that you and the few remaining personnel are on your own. Inside this facility, though are a bunch of tight corridors, and that's about it. Again, some people hate that, but to me claustrophobia is another plus factor to the atmosphere. The game is meant to be intense, even when nothing is going on, and the feeling of being trapped does just that.

With the exception of reloading, the gunplay feels classic. You have to put a bunch of rounds into the enemies to kill them, and some of the larger enemies will require multiple reloads with smaller weapons. Circle strafing is a must in larger areas, but you'll have to do a lot of popping in and out of cover or tactically charge or retreat in most cases. It has the same sort of feel as Doom, just a bit modernized (for 2004) and stylized.

The game has a few flaws, though, but they can mostly just be ignored. The AI is a little lackluster at times. There are small closet-sized rooms which serve simply to open silently behind you and release an enemy. The darkness might strain your eyes a bit, so playing for a couple hours might be a bit uncomfortable. To some, the gameplay might get repetitive. But for me, the strengths far outweighed these few weaknesses. This is definitely a recommend.
Wish there was controller support, otherwise great game.

Good sci-fi horror game. Has a survival horror pace, not run and gun like classic Doom. It is a physically dark game, so if that's not your thing you might not love it. The graphics hold up reasonably well, though not as impressively as Half-life 2's. Turn up the volume and turn out the lights for the best experience. This original version is artistically superior to the BFG edition. Great atmosphere, sound, and story, I think they did a great job at realizing the Doom world! Great game for anyone who enjoys horror or science fiction.

Totally worth it if you like action and adventure on the planet Mars!  I give it a 10/10 just because its an old game and was one of the best in its time period during the release.  Even has an expansion!

It's not a sequel to the wildly entertaining classic Doom titles, which I still play competitively with friends to this day, it's Doom: Bland FPS.  Though still more entertaining than Call of Duty and the likes, with a meaty single player campaign, it acts as more of a tech demo than a fully-fleshed Doom title.
Gives you what you pay pay for. Really, very staisfied with my purchase.

So Steam Roulette selected DOOM3 to be game #2 of this year's Steam Backlog Blitz. At first I was kinda excited as I hadn't really touched DOOM3 since I bought x amount of years ago. I was recommended to download and use the sikkmod, which I too would recommend. Provides some nicely updated graphics and options to play around with.

First thing I will say about this game is that it's long. Certainly long for a FPS, even more so compared to modern standards. You'll easily be playing this game for 12+ hours, which could be a good or a bad thing depending on what you like from a FPS.
I personally found it a little too long, and according to Steam it took me 19 hours to finish this... It's a very slow paced game, which is odd for a DOOM title. Some might like that, but if you've grown up with DOOM and even DOOM II then it's a strange experience. They could easily have dropped a level or two from the middle of the game, or even had more 'traditional DOOM' levels as replacements.
However, the slow pace of the game is highlighted nicely by the lighting and the sound within the game. I know some people didn't like the torch/weapon swapping, but I found it increased the level of tension within the game (however I did find it led to an increased level of bordem at times). Yet, the cheap scares and the over use of the one scare tactic do become tiresome very quickly.

Overall it was an OK experience, if a little too long and not as frantic as I expected. Graphics, lighting and atmosphere are still good today as they would have been back in 2004. So credit must go to ID for that. If you play this in bitesized chunks you'll probably avoid the feeling of the game dragging on.
If you see this cheap in the sales, have a good pair of headphones, and turn the lights off... you're in for a decent experience.

reviewText: I will start off by saying I love this game.\nDoom 3 is an amazing FPS for hardcore FPS players. It looks, acts, and feels like a true shooter. Being an experienced FPS-player I can tell you I highly recommend this game to anyone wanting to get their shooter fix. The game puts adequate emphasis on a superb storyline and classic FPS mechanics. The graphics are great for a video game developed in the early 2000's, and I haven't seen an FPS for PC that's this polished and made at the same time. The diversed weapon variety and non-repetitive level design is top-notch, and anyone should give this game a change. Shame on them if they don't favor it for whatever reason.

reviewText:
It's Doom. Demons, aliens, Mars, Hell, and (not quite enough time spent with) the BFG9000. The game spends a little too much time on the theme of survival horror, a few too many zombies in dark corners, jump scares, unlit areas, enemy-spawns-behind-you and all that. Though it is definitely fun to play alone in the dark at night and come across that one area every now and you're so hesitant to proceed, you feel like you yourself are in danger. But it retains the over all theme of the franchise with Hell and aliens and it's a very fun game over all that has aged very gracefully.

Pros:

Terrifying to play in the dark
I never get tired of fighting Imps
Still has great graphics, lighting and animations
Great sound as well
(with a couple exceptions) awesome re-designs of the classic enemies
A fairly challenging game
BFG!!!

Cons:

Too much wandering through the dark/too many jump scares
Not as high octane as the original games
Not enough BFG!!!

It's a classic game in it's own right.

reviewText:
Doom 3 is a long-awaited game of Doom franchise, a dark first-person shooter and sequel to icon of FPS games. It was developed and released by id Software in 2004, after few delays and annual showcases at E3, with one of those alpha versions of a game ending up leaked. It differs in that it takes more on slower survival horror side while still remaining an old-school shooter. Even if very slow one.
It also got remade/remastered as part of BFG Edition deal, where it was brightened up, eliminating darkness aspect of gameplay. If you are one of those people who agree with joke that to copy Doom 3 gameplay you just have to turn off monitor screen and then direct flashlight at it, then you better check that version out instead.
It also was ported to Xbox. Sure thing it was cut down and simplicifed, but overall stayed true to the source. Didn't play it myself. One nice feature it had over PC version was 2-player coop, with levels being edited to fit into such gameplay. But since Xbox Live service was shut down it's not actual anymore. Sadly.

And so after launching the game and choosing ultra-quality, while laughing as I remember my old PC back few years ago struggling with low-quality setting and even freezing, I started a new game. And was awed. By how much more ugly it was compared to clean image I had in my memories.
You see, the game fails to recognise memory amount on modern hardware correctly and so it sets the textures quality to the minimum. Tweaking settings in-game will not change it. Instead you have to go to game folder and edit config file. I recommend looking at PCGamingWiki site which has a good example of Autoexec file.

But the small graphical problems still remained. Perhaps it's because I tweaked config files manually, but I had a few glitches. First, corpses of non-demons (and spiders) behaved funnily when gibbed. They would start dissintegrating, then when almost finished they would suddenly go back to look same as before, just without heads, and then they just suddenly dissapear few seconds later.
Another rendering problem would occur after getting to the next level during gameplay, where lights/shadows will start to slowly glitch out slightly here and there. Got tiresome to restart the game after few levels. Some on other hand were complained about objects fully dissapearing, so watch out.
And strangely enough game stutters here and there even on modern hardware. Some blame Steam version.

Nope, no widescreen by default. But people would just tweak config file and I never heard any complaining. Didn't check myself.

Multiplayer community is pretty much dead, I didn't find anybody playing game. Aside from that one time where they were playing on server with some mod, but I failed to join. So I don't have vanilla experience. From what I can tell multiplayer was pretty much tucked on the game, it being a small-scaled deathmatch, with 4 players limit. Things move fast though and even keeps same shadow play as single-player game. Still, I doubt that it was all that hot.
Community made a coop mod, by the way, maybe it's worth checking out with a friend.

Plot follows a lone space marine, who is not same guy as that Doom guy from original. And you are this time on Mars, where UA Corporations is having teleporter experiements, with half of a staff having asian look. After a short introudction levels, hell will break loose.

And so Doom 3, while keeping arsenal fo weapons and monster types recognisable from the original Doom games, albeit with style change, leans onto more of Survival Horror aspect. Now, mind it, it still has you run'n'gunning. Well, walk'n'gunning, as the game became much more slower-paced. You will walk slower and you will encounter far lesser enemies, somewhere like Quake 1. Which means less but a bit tougher. You will also have monsters ambushing you often, pouncing at you as soon as door opens and test your reaction like that, as well as just spawning into room. Spawn takes ages however and by the time that monster will actually teleport in you will be already aiming your shotgun up-close at the main mass.

Yes, it has design hiccups. But it does excells in atmoshpere and one of the main unique things it brings in is light/shadow play. As you know, engine blew everybody mind, at least in 2002 E3 event, with combination of bump-mapping and dynamic shadows, with shadow rendering the same no matter if it's level or model. While being sexily precise. While other games in the end would just put it in for farts, Doom 3 used it to enhance the style and gameplay. And boy, does it look still awesome. Not as pretty as Half-Life 2, mind it, but I really wanted to screenshot occasional room, seeing how all the monsters, bump-shaded sci-fi textures and action is illuminated. Shame that screenshot function on Steam overlay was disabled.

It also bring a thing or two in gameplay. Darkness is often covering parts of a room. You can either hold a flashlight or use a weapon, never both. As a result, you have to decide if you want to see where monster is or just shoot blindly. Actually, I pretty much recommend you to use flashlight as little as possible and never in a firefight. This way you will actually will be more effective, as you will learn to recognise monsters by the little lights they give away, whether fireballs or just their eyes, as well as recognising that monster is there by sounds they make. Most memoriable scene for me was after imp, fireball throwing medium demon, killed the only light in a room and two more arrived soon, as I had to tell away where they were by the light that their fireballs emitted.
No other FPS would combine both old-school shooting and survival horror aspect this way.

Well, if forget that for survival horror it gives way too much ammo. Or even for standard FPS. That, or maybe that's because I opened every closet. You see, game placed a lot of devices around the levels that would show you email and audio log of some person. They are mostly there to improve backstory. And to reward players who read them developers would put closet codes into logs too. But to be honest, while amusing, they weren't exciting and it only putted away players who didn't care about those things.
Was quite easy on Normal too. Should had increased difficulty. Hmmm.
Also, two lockers want you to check easter egg websites that actually was on Internet. If forget that it not redirects you to Doom3BFG site. Just search through some easter eggs website.

And yes, it tries to scare player all the time. And to be honest, it doesn't work. Not even as jumpscares. Or maybe it wasn't intented to be truly scary. In all honesty I just recommend to immerse yourself into atmoshpere and enjoy all the freaky stuff going on, taking it as a just cool special effect. Relax and enjoy.
Game also doesn't use music tracks, instead putting combination of ambient sound into every room. Some of those sounds were quite musical. It was a good experiement idea, but fails in this case, as I don't remember anything good. But I guess it works. Could use proper ambient track though.

It still is clunky at times, gameplay isn't as smooth as in original Doom. For example Shotgun isn't all that reliable, it can shoot in such way that every pellet will be outside of a center. Or focused on one side. Most of encounters don't last long. Melee zombies are just there to be beaten up by flashlight. It also overuses futurustic base setting, only once breaking into Hell level or such. Now, I loved taking slow and being careful in these dark rooms of UAC base, but even I grew tired toward the end. That and final boss sucks.
And well, it's plainly way too long for what it is.

But in the end, Doom 3 still manages to fill the niche. But you gotta love slow-paced actiony gameplay and to appericate some shadow work. Even if it's not 2004 anymore, it still looks nice too. And just have to be in the mood to love it.

reviewText:
Almost equal part survival horror game and shooter, Doom 3 is a departure from the original classics. Blaring MIDI metal and full speed circle strafing gives way to silence and methodically checking every corner for monsters. The story is surprisingly lengthy and involved, taking inspiration from the Alien films with a demonic Starship Troopers B-movie vibe. It was somewhat divisive when it originally released; the slower pace and heavy reliance on light management wasn't helped by the concurrent rise of the vocal, entitled, forum-dwelling “gamer” that was adverse to change of any kind. This backlash quickly led to a popular “flashlight mod” for the game; a cheat that bypassed the need to switch from your weapon to your light source and completely changed the nature of play. Once this “fix” was in circulation and accepted as a superior way to play the game, subsequent releases (the BFG Edition) used it as a new standard with no option to experience the game as originally intended. A decade later, it's pretty clear those people were wrong. The BFG Edition of Doom 3 is a fairly forgettable corridor shooter. This true version of Doom 3 is still fantastic and is much more influential than anyone seems to give it credit for.

Lighting is a central mechanic to Doom 3. While some of the character models and textures are starting to show their age, the lighting effects and art direction are still incredibly impressive. You use the “F” key to switch to your flashlight frequently; much of the game is filled with moody shadows and often complete pitch blackness. It's not uncommon to have to make a choice to either aim for a demon's glowing red eyes or lure it toward a more helpful light source, hoping you don't back into a trap in the process. It's ballsy how willing Doom 3 is to engulf the player in darkness, knowing their choice is to either be able to see or defend themselves. You can't do both. Walking through hostile environments armed with only a flashlight is it's own genre now; Outlast, Slender Man, Alien: Isolation... that disempowerment was a cornerstone of Doom 3.

Most of the weapons and enemies from the previous games return: the possessed soldiers, the standard Imps, floating Cacodemons, dead-raising Revenants, towering Hellknights, and the big bad Cyberdemon. A few new ones make their appearances, notably the weak but swarming spiders and creepy winged baby things. Then there are standard zombies, which aren't much of a threat on their own but have a habit of trapping you in corners if you're not careful. They're also great chainsaw fodder. Weapons include the all-around handy shotgun, the hammering chaingun, plasma gun, a new standard if generic assault rifle, and the legendary BFG. Ammo conservation and choosing the right tool for the right situation seems more vital than ever, as weapons have a pretty clear rock-paper-scissors relationship to most monsters. And the monsters can be right aggressive ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, relentlessly chasing you down and teleporting toward or behind you. Some attacks and scripted “jump scares” seem almost impossible to avoid damage from, causing health and ammo rationing to ratchet up to true survival horror levels. Also new (though introduced late in the game) is the Soul Cube, an alien artifact that charges up by killing five enemies, which can then be thrown for massive damage and health regeneration. It's an odd weapon, but it does add an additional layer of strategy as you prioritize low ranking demons for the charge to obliterate the tougher foes.

A gripping narrative and the Doom name doesn't exactly go hand-in-hand, but a surprising amount of care went into building the game's lore and the pacing is actually spot on. You play The Marine, a voiceless guy who shows up on a Mars base in the future. Almost immediately ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan and the base's personnel gets a bad case of the Satans and demons start coming through portals. There's a mad scientist intent on helping the demons (or something), and the demons want to ultimately conquer Earth because they're actually an ancient race that humans have descended from. It's real campy schlock, but it's very self aware and dips into outright comedy at times, then presents truly dark and disturbing imagery in the next beat. I'd describe the tone as The Evil Dead meets Aliens.

You interact with the environments in a number of ways to solve puzzles; many of the computers can be cursored over in order to raise bridges, move machinery, or access camera or communication feeds. It's quite an impressive level of detail, mechanics that predated modern games like SOMA, Dead Space, and Alien: Isolation (again...). In addition to the standard finding of keycards and badges to raise your security clearance and unlock doors, Doom 3 features another form of storytelling collectible that has become prolific enough to become a cliché: audio logs and e-mails. Now, this certainly isn't the first video game to have the player sift through characters' personal files, but the game came out well before the method had overstayed it's welcome and is still some of the best implementation I've come across. Some of the exchanges between staff are genuinely funny, and the Martian Buddy spam is a forgotten classic. Even the video discs have a distinct style and personality, and even if some of this fluff can be criticized for slowing the game down, it's optional and I enjoyed diving into every last one. It can't be understated how great (and often tense) it is to be able to listen to audio logs as you explore and fight; something other games still screw up to this day.

Doom 3 holds up better than just about any other game of it's vintage I can think of. It remains super tense and oppressive, and I found myself leaning toward the screen as I played with baited breath. With a good pair of headphones and a darkened room it's just as effective (if not more so) than most modern horror games. When the bullets and fireballs start flying it's still definitely classic Doom, but the new emphasis on narrative and lore-building allow the masterfully crafted, cramped hellish battlefields to legitimately scare the crap out of you. It plays silky smooth while still feeling brutal and visceral. Doom 3 may be a different breed of Doom, but now when it kicks ♥♥♥ you might just ♥♥♥♥ yourself in the process.

reviewText:
You battle your way through dark corridors, blood soaked rooms and Martian terrain killing zombies, fire imps and all sorts of strange creatures. I suppose you can say Doom 3 is not an 'original' game in its ideas, but that won’t bother you once you get totally absorbed into it's environment. Like the original Doom, it has the end of level 'bosses' and you get all the good weapons right until the end when you have to battle the infamous Cyberdemon.
The look of the game is amazing, with fantastic light and shadows (rather more of the latter than former) and innovative use of interactive computer screens. The sound is close to perfect.
The atmosphere of the game is unparalleled, keeping you permanently alert. The few scenarios where the game uses psychological horror are very effective.
On the other hand, the game sometimes gets repetitive. Although most of the game manages to hold your interest, there seems to be a lot of filler" missions reminiscent of older id titles: get key to open door / find an access code / etc. This is particularly the case in the middle of the game when
recommended: you begin to feel that the game ought to advance the plot a bit or give you something else to do rather than shooting imps and wandering some uninspired corridors. It does eventually liven up a bit
hoursPlayed: but the game would be much improved by some more variety.\nSome of the combat is also unfair
voteText: with monsters teleporting directly behind you. This can get annoying
helpfulPercent: but doesn't harm the horror aspect of the game at all as it keeps you permanently on edge.\nOverall
votesHelpful: a rather unique game which is well worth playing.\n"
